title: Algorithm
description: An algorithm is a well-defined procedure or formula for solving a problem or completing a specific task, often designed to run efficiently on a computer.

title: Sorting Algorithm
description: Sorting algorithms are used to arrange data in a particular order, such as ascending or descending. Common examples include QuickSort, MergeSort, and BubbleSort.

title: Search Algorithm
description: Search algorithms are used to retrieve information from a data structure. Examples include Binary Search, Depth-First Search (DFS), and Breadth-First Search (BFS).

title: Time Complexity
description: Time complexity is a measure of the time an algorithm takes to run as a function of the size of its input, commonly expressed using Big O notation.

title: Big O Notation
description: Big O Notation is used to describe the upper bound of an algorithm's time complexity, giving the worst-case scenario in terms of execution time.

title: Space Complexity
description: Space complexity refers to the amount of memory an algorithm requires as it processes data, also typically described using Big O notation.

title: Greedy Algorithm
description: A greedy algorithm is one that makes a sequence of choices, each of which looks best at the moment, with the goal of finding the global optimum.

title: Dynamic Programming
description: Dynamic programming is a method for solving complex problems by breaking them down into simpler subproblems, which are solved once and stored for future use.

title: Divide and Conquer
description: Divide and Conquer is a strategy that involves breaking a problem into smaller, more manageable subproblems, solving each subproblem, and then combining the results.

title: Graph Algorithms
description: Graph algorithms are used to solve problems related to graphs, such as finding the shortest path, detecting cycles, and traversing nodes.

title: Hashing
description: Hashing is a technique used to map data of arbitrary size to fixed-size values, which are typically used for fast data retrieval.

title: Binary Search
description: Binary search is a fast search algorithm that works on sorted arrays by repeatedly dividing the search interval in half.

title: Recursion
description: Recursion is a technique where a function calls itself to solve a problem, often used in algorithms that can be defined in terms of simpler versions of themselves.

title: Backtracking
description: Backtracking is an algorithmic technique for solving problems recursively by trying to build a solution incrementally and removing solutions that fail to satisfy constraints.

title: Graph Traversal
description: Graph traversal algorithms like DFS and BFS are used to visit all the nodes or vertices in a graph systematically.

title: Linked List
description: A linked list is a data structure consisting of nodes where each node contains data and a reference to the next node in the sequence.

title: Stack
description: A stack is a data structure that follows the Last In, First Out (LIFO) principle, where elements are added and removed from the top.

title: Queue
description: A queue is a data structure that follows the First In, First Out (FIFO) principle, where elements are added at the back and removed from the front.

title: Heap
description: A heap is a special tree-based data structure that satisfies the heap property, often used to implement priority queues.

title: Tree
description: A tree is a hierarchical data structure with a root node and child nodes, commonly used to represent hierarchical relationships.

title: Binary Tree
description: A binary tree is a tree data structure where each node has at most two children, referred to as the left child and the right child.

title: AVL Tree
description: An AVL tree is a self-balancing binary search tree where the height difference between left and right subtrees is at most one.

title: Red-Black Tree
description: A Red-Black tree is a self-balancing binary search tree where nodes are colored red or black to ensure balance during insertions and deletions.

title: Trie
description: A trie is a tree-like data structure used to store a dynamic set of strings, where each node represents a common prefix.

title: B-Tree
description: A B-tree is a self-balancing tree data structure that maintains sorted data and allows for efficient insertion, deletion, and search operations.

title: Normalization
description: Normalization is the process of organizing data in a database to reduce redundancy and improve data integrity, typically by dividing large tables into smaller ones.

title: Denormalization
description: Denormalization is the process of combining normalized tables to improve read performance at the expense of write performance and data integrity.

title: SQL
description: SQL (Structured Query Language) is a standardized language for managing and manipulating relational databases.

title: NoSQL
description: NoSQL databases are non-relational databases designed for large-scale data storage and for data models that don't fit well into relational schemas.

title: ACID Properties
description: ACID stands for Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, and Durability, which are the key properties that ensure reliable processing of database transactions.

title: CAP Theorem
description: CAP Theorem states that a distributed database system can only guarantee two out of the three properties: Consistency, Availability, and Partition tolerance.

title: Indexing
description: Indexing is a database optimization technique that allows for faster retrieval of records from a database by creating data structures that point to the actual records.

title: Join
description: A join is an SQL operation that combines rows from two or more tables based on a related column between them.

title: Primary Key
description: A primary key is a unique identifier for a record in a database table, ensuring that each record can be uniquely identified.

title: Foreign Key
description: A foreign key is a field in a database table that creates a link between two tables, enforcing referential integrity between the child and parent tables.

title: Sharding
description: Sharding is a database partitioning technique that splits large databases into smaller, faster, and more manageable parts called shards.

title: Replication
description: Replication is the process of copying and maintaining database objects, such as tables, in multiple database servers to ensure redundancy and improve data availability.

title: Database Index
description: A database index is a data structure that improves the speed of data retrieval operations on a database table at the cost of additional storage and maintenance.

title: Query Optimization
description: Query optimization involves modifying a database query to improve its efficiency, typically by reducing the time it takes to execute the query.

title: Stored Procedure
description: A stored procedure is a set of SQL statements that can be stored in the database and executed as a program to perform a specific task.
